translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter🔽The Chapter about Desires
The Great Monkey Jātaka
There was a king in Bārāṇasī,
an augmenter of the Kāsī country;
Surrounded by friends and counselors,
he came to the Deer Park.
There he saw a brahmin,
white, variegated, and emaciated;
His hands and feet cut off, like a koviḷāra flower,
lean, with veins protruding.🔽Having seen that man in distress,
who had attained supreme compassion,
The king spoke from a distance:
Which of the yakkhas are you?
Your hands and feet are white,
and your head is even whiter;
Your body is the color of cotton wool,
and you are full of emaciation.
Your ribs are like a braided rope,
your back is sunken and raised;
Your limbs are like black rocks,
I see no one like you.
With feet like a bellows, exhausted,
lean, with veins protruding;

translated: Emaciated, you look terrible,

analyzed: kutas asi kattha gacchasi  duddasī appakāro asi
translated: where are you from, where are you going?🔽Hard to look at, you have little strength,
ugly, terrifying to behold;
Even your mother, who gave birth to you,
would not want to see you.
“What deed did you do in the past,
whom did you strike down out of hatred;
Having done what wicked deed,
have you come to this suffering?”
“Indeed I will tell you,
as much as I am able;
For in the world, the truthful,
are praised by the wise.
Wandering alone, seeking cows,
confused, I entered a dense forest;
In the wilderness, in a ravine, in a jungle,
frequented by various elephants.
Followed by wild beasts,
I was lost in the forest;
I wandered there for seven days,
afflicted by hunger and thirst.
There I saw a tinduka tree,
standing unevenly, hungry;
Hanging down to the ground,
bearing ripe fruit.
I ate the wind-blown fruits,
they suited me very well;
Greedy, I climbed the tree,
thinking to stay there comfortably.
One was eaten by me,
the second was desired;
Then that tree broke its branch,
like it was cut by an axe.
I, together with the branches,
fell down head over heels,
On a steep mountain, on a crag,
with no foothold or support.
But because the water was deep,
therefore I did not cross over;
There I lay, without joy,
for ten nights, not less than that.
Then a monkey came there,
a forest-dweller, with a goiter on his neck;
Moving from branch to branch,
eating the fruit of the trees.
Seeing me, thin and pale,
he took pity on me;
“Who are you, sir, here,
afflicted with such suffering?
Are you a human or a non-human,
tell me who you are;

analyzed: tassa añjalim paṇāmetvā  idam vacanam abravi
translated: Having paid homage to him,🔽I spoke this statement:
“I am a human who has fallen into misfortune,
I have no way out from here;
I tell you this, may you be fortunate,
and be my refuge.
Taking a heavy rock,
the monkey wandered on the mountain;
Having made a bridge with the rock,
the powerful one spoke this:
“Come, mount on my back,
and hold my neck with your arms;
I will pull you out,
from the steep mountain, with speed.”
Having heard his words,
of the glorious lord of the monkeys,
I climbed onto the back of the wise one,
and held onto his neck with my arms.
Then he rose up from there,
the powerful and radiant monkey,
and with difficulty and pain,
he quickly went to the mountain peak.
Having lifted me up, the peaceful one,
the bull, said this to me:
“Come on, my dear, protect me,
I will be a beast for a moment.
Lions, tigers, and leopards,
the colour of peacocks and partridges;
They might harm me if I am careless,
having seen them, you must stop them.”
Thus he was protected by me,
that beast for a moment;
Then I abandoned the wrong view,
that was not in accordance with reason.
“This is food for humans,
just like other deer in the forest;
Now if I were to kill him,
and eat the cooked monkey,
I would go without being seen,
taking the meat, the provisions;
I would cross the desert,
it would be my provisions.”
Then taking a rock,
I struck him on the head.
The blow to my dear one,
was weak.
And he, coming quickly,
covered with blood,
with eyes full of tears,
looked at me.
‘Do not kill me, dear one,
you are a good monkey.
And you, Dīghāvu,
are able to ward off others.
Oh, you are a man,
doing such a difficult deed!
Such a rough and difficult path,
a precipice, I was thrown down.
Brought from the other world,
you thought me to be a fraud;
By that wicked one,
wicked thoughts were thought of me.
Do not, you who are established in unrighteousness,
experience painful feelings!
Do not, you who are established in unrighteousness,
experience the fruit of your evil deed!
These three have no trust,
wicked ones, who are not restrained;
Come, go behind me,
while being seen, close by.
You are freed from the hands of the wild beasts,
you have attained human status;
This is the path, you who are established in unrighteousness,
go by it as you like.’
Having said this, the mountain-dweller,
and fell on my head;
I rubbed my tears away,
and then climbed up the mountain.
I was afflicted by that,
and burned with fever;
With my body burning,
I went to drink water.
The lake was covered with algae,

analyzed: rahadaḥ ruhira makkhito  pubba lohita saṅkāsaḥ
translated: like a fire burning with flames;
All of it turned into🔽pus and blood.
As many drops of water
as fell on my body,
That many boils arose,
like half-rotten beluva wood.
My boils burst and oozed out,
pus and blood;
Wherever I went,
in villages and towns,
People with sticks in their hands
stopped me, both women and men;
‘Don’t come near us, you stinking corpse,
you’re covered in pus and blood.’
Such is my suffering,
now for seven years;
I experience my own deeds,
the evil I did in the past.
I tell you this, good sirs,
all of you who have gathered here;
Don’t be treacherous to your friends,
for treachery to friends is evil.
He becomes a leper, a leper,
who betrays his friends.
When his body breaks up, the betrayer of friends
is reborn in hell.”
The Hare-Jackal Birth Story is the sixth.
